 Here's something I have stored in my personal notes.
 
 
 
 A couple of other perplexing evolutionary questions:
 
 1) How could multicellularity arise?
 
 2) How could sexual reproduction arise?
 
 It's not actually all that difficult to conceptualize a solution to the first: only two main steps are needed.
 
 
 1a) Unicellular organisms clump together to form a colony: each individual is autonomous and identical
 
 1b) Some of the cells in the clump differentiate: for example, some become specialized for reproduction
 
 
 
 A series for the second question might be more difficult to conceptualize, but we can at least cover a good deal of it.
 
 2a) Meiosis arises (the part not explained here)
 
 2b) Two identical haploid gametes - which swim by means of flagella - merge to form a new individual
 
 2c) The two swimming gametes produced come to be of different sizes, but otherwise are still fundamentally alike
 
 2d) The larger, less mobile gamete loses its flagellum and becomes immobile
 
 2e) The large, immobile gamete becomes specialized for storing nutrients and cytoplasmic determinants, while the other, mobile gamete becomes specialized for delivering just a nucleus
 
 
 
 And lucky for us, we can even see such intermediate forms, for both 1 and 2, in a single group of organisms!
 
 
"The Volvocaceans
 
 The simpler organisms among the volvocaceans are ordered assemblies of numerous cells, each resembling the unicellular protist Chlamydomonas, to which they are related (Figure 2.11A). A single organism of the volvocacean genus Gonium (Figure 2.11B), for example, consists of a flat plate of 4 to 16 cells, each with its own flagellum. In a related genus, Pandorina, the 16 cells form a sphere (Figure 2.11C); and in Eudorina, the sphere contains 32 or 64 cells arranged in a regular pattern (Figure 2.11D). In these organisms, then, a very important developmental principle has been worked out: the ordered division of one cell to generate a number of cells that are organized in a predictable fashion. As occurs during cleavage in most animal embryos, the cell divisions by which a single volvocacean cell produces an organism of 4 to 64 cells occur in very rapid sequence and in the absence of cell growth.
 
 The next two genera of the volvocacean series exhibit another important principle of development: the differentiation of cell types within an individual organism. The reproductive cells become differentiated from the somatic cells. In all the genera mentioned earlier, every cell can, and normally does, produce a complete new organism by mitosis. In the genera Pleodorina and Volvox, however, relatively few cells can reproduce. In Pleodorina californica (Figure 2.11E), the cells in the anterior region are restricted to a somatic function; only those cells on the posterior side can reproduce. In P. californica, a colony usually has 128 or 64 cells, and the ratio of the number of somatic cells to the number of reproductive cells is usually 3:5. Thus, a 128-cell colony typically has 48 somatic cells, and a 64-cell colony has 24.
 
 In Volvox, almost all the cells are somatic, and very few of the cells are able to produce new individuals. In some species of Volvox, reproductive cells, as in Pleodorina, are derived from cells that originally look and function like somatic cells before they enlarge and divide to form new progeny. However, in other members of the genus, such as V. carteri, there is a complete division of labor: the reproductive cells that will create the next generation are set aside during the division of the original cell that is forming a new individual. The reproductive cells never develop functional flagella and never contribute to motility or other somatic functions of the individual; they are entirely specialized for reproduction. Thus, although the simpler volvocaceans may be thought of as colonial organisms (because each cell is capable of independent existence and of perpetuating the species), in V. carteri we have a truly multicellular organism with two distinct and interdependent cell types (somatic and reproductive), both of which are required for perpetuation of the species (Figure 2.11F). Although not all animals set aside the reproductive cells from the somatic cells (and plants hardly ever do), this separation of germ cells from somatic cells early in development is characteristic of many animal phyla and will be discussed in more detail in Chapter 19.
 
 Although all the volvocaceans, like their unicellular relative Chlamydomonas, reproduce predominantly by asexual means, they are also capable of sexual reproduction, which involves the production and fusion of haploid gametes. In many species of Chlamydomonas, including the one illustrated in Figure 2.10, sexual reproduction is isogamous ("the same gametes"), since the haploid gametes that meet are similar in size, structure, and motility. However, in other species of Chlamydomonasas well as many species of colonial volvocaceans swimming gametes of very different sizes are produced by the different mating types. This pattern is called heterogamy ("different gametes"). But the larger volvocaceans have evolved a specialized form of heterogamy, called oogamy, which involves the production of large, relatively immotile eggs by one mating type and small, motile sperm by the other (see Sidelights and Speculations). Here we see one type of gamete specialized for the retention of nutritional and developmental resources and the other type of gamete specialized for the transport of nuclei. Thus, the volvocaceans include the simplest organisms that have distinguishable male and female members of the species and that have distinct developmental pathways for the production of eggs or sperm. In all the volvocaceans, the fertilization reaction resembles that of Chlamydomonas in that it results in the production of a dormant diploid zygote, which is capable of surviving harsh environmental conditions. When conditions allow the zygote to germinate, it first undergoes meiosis to produce haploid offspring of the two different mating types in equal numbers. "
 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=dbio.section.203)

Instead of debating semantics, I will try to offer a sort of explanation.
 
 I will start by saying that God cannot be disproven. Any test anywhere could be an instance where God did not interfere, simply allowing nature to take its course. But there is no evidence that supports the existence of God either. If a supernatural creator did exist, we would expect to see some sort of supernatural occurrence which one might find consistant with the idea of a creator. Not only have we not seen this, we have not seen any evidence of any supernatural power anywhere at any time. Yet even this is not enough to disprove God, for God may merely have never exerted any supernatural power that can be observed. God cannot be disproven.
 
 But I don't think one needs to disprove the existence of God in order to not believe in God. For just as much as God cannot be disproven, neither can vampires, dragons, or pixies. I can say, "no one has ever seen any evidence that vampires, dragons, or pixies exist, so although some people in the past wrote about them, it is really no more likely that these things exist than that anything my mind can randomly think up exists." I can say the same thing about God.
 
 So when someone says, "I don't believe in vampires", do you ask them to prove that vampires don't exist? Certainly not. When someone says, "I don't believe in chimera," do we ask them to prove that chimera don't exist? If you tell me that you don't believe in the Egyptian god named Horus, do I ask you to prove that he does not exist? Certainly not; although we cannot disprove these things, there is just no evidence that they actually exist.
 
 Hopefully it should be clear then, that someone who is debating the existence of something must provide evidence that this thing exists. The idea that God exists is not supported by science or reasoning; it is supported only by faith.
 
 Getting back to the initial discussion; the idea that evolution takes place is supported by scientific reasoning, logic, evidence, and its ability to predict scientific discoveries and help scientists determine where to look next. Creationism is not.

You appear to be asserting above that it takes faith to believe in the non-existence of X. (If I misinterpret your position, feel free to clarify.) My position is that if there is no evidence of X, then it is reasonable to conclude that there is no logical reason to believe in the existence of X. This takes no faith. (Consider definition #2 at Dictionary.com: "2. Belief that does not rest on logical proof or material evidence.") Rather, it takes reason and logic.
 
 Now, if one were to claim that "It is 100% certain that X does not exist!" then we would ask them to produce evidence to back up that statement. I think this is probably where you are coming from. As far as I can see, no one on this thread has suggested that it is 100% certain that X does not exist. As far as I can see, others are saying essentially the same thing that I'm saying: "There is no logical reason to conclude that X exists if there is no evidence that X exists." It is still possible that X exists. But not logical. Nor reasonable. In the realm of the imagination, anything is possible. But in the realm of the physical universe, there appears to be some limitations as to what is possible.
 Peace,

 My "claims" are not at all off topic. That you don't understand the relevance doesn't mean there is none. This fallacy of arrogance is a hallmark of mature debate. Instead of merely asking for the relevance, you assume there is none. My "claims" attempt to show that you don't understand the implications of your position: That if the claimant of a negative claim does not have the burden of proof, he can create all kinds of idiotic claims that are essentially impossible to defeat. 
 
 Your (apparent) position that the claimant is burdened only if it his claim could be logically supported (when proving such a claim is not illogical) is lunacy. You seem to be arguing that the more idiotic the claim, the less liable the claimant should be. That's makes zero sense to me. People should not be rewarded for making idiotic claims. Nobody is being forced to make a negative claim. If a negative claim is folly, then I can see no logical reason why such claimants should be bailed out.
 
 An additional problem with assignment of burden to the "affirmative position" is that it assumes that the "affirmative position" is the necessary counter to a negative claim. In this case of "god didn't do it", the objection may be epistemological. If that is the case, it may be that the assumed "affirmative position" (god did do it) also has epistemological problems. In this case, the "affirmative position" is in a double bind: he cannot argue epistemologically against the claimant's position without sabotaging the "affirmative position" as well. This is doubly bad, because the claimant is under no compunction to defend his position, since the burden has been shifted to the "affirmative position". It is triply bad, because the claimant can then just self-immolate (deny his own position) and win the debate on epistemological grounds. Therefore, in general there should be no assumption that the "affirmative position" exists, until such a claim is made. An affirmative position is one alternative to counter a negative claim, but not the only one.
 
 If placing the burden of proof on the claimant of "god didn't do it" is repugnant, consider the analogous case for the claim "the big bang didn't do it". In the latter case, is the opponent forced into the position of "the big bang did it" and has the burden of proof on him? Well, we can't have it both ways.

One reason that you are wrong is that you are using the word "theory" with two different meanings, since the theory of creation is a religious assertion and the theory of evolution is a scientific concept. In other words, you are using both the common definition of the word (a guess or speculation) in the case of creation theory, and a set of statement or principles devised and tested that explain a group of facts or phenomena. Actually, the creation theory isn't even a theory in the vernacular sense, since it is a religious assertion based on unobserved, untested dogma.
 
 Most creationists rank ideas in the order of their importance as follows: Hypotheses -< Theories -< Laws -< Facts. Most creationists don't realize, and even when they are told refuse to accept that scientists rank the importance differently: Facts -< Hypotheses -< Laws -< Theories.
 
 Let me say that again so that I'm sure that you understand what I'm saying. The common use of the word theory refers to a wild guess that is unsupported by any empirical observation. In science, a theory is as good as it gets - a theory is predictive and has been strictly tested and found correct.
 
 Some examples of scientific theories are the theory of gravity, the germ theory of disease, the heliocentric theory, atomic theory, nuclear theory (that is used to build bombs and run nuclear power plants), the theory of relativity, plate tectonic theory, and of course, the big bang theory.

 You are using the word "theory" in its common usage, not its scientific usage. The question is whether 'creationism" is a "scientific theory". 
 
 A scientific theory is a hypothesis (that has been reached through research) then is tested and re-evaluated and when thought to be the best answer to the original problem that the hypothesis was created to resolve, is then put through rigorous peer review by other scientists in the field before determined to be a scientific theory.
 
 Neither Creationism nor Intelligent Design has even reached the hypothesis stage which requires stating the problem and then doing the appropriate scientific research to form a hypothesis.

 5th day - it was good. 22 And God blessed them, saying, Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth. 23 And the evening and the morning were the fifth day.
 6th day - THIS IS WHERE WE COME IN!! YAY! And God made the beast of the earth after his kind, and cattle after their kind, and every thing that creepeth upon the earth after his kind: and God saw that it was good. 26 And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth. 27 So God created man in his own image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them. 28 And God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moveth upon the earth. 29 And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in the which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat. 30 And to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein there is life, I have given every green herb for meat: and it was so. 31 And God saw every thing that he had made, and, behold, it was very good. And the evening and the morning were the sixth day. 
 THEN THE 7TH DAY .... God rested. because he saw all was good.
 
 
 Let me point out some discrepancies in this genesis account of 6-day creation (+ 1 day of rest):
 1) The creation of the Moon on the 4th day is out of place with the creation of seed plants on the 3rd day, since we now know that Moon rock dates at 4 1/2 billion years while seed bearing plants came much later during the Mesozoic Era less than 1/4 billion years ago.
 2) Fish, being created on the 5th day, are out of sequence here with seed plants on the 3rd day since the earliest fish date to the Cambrian period 1/2 billion years ago.
 3) Reptiles that "creepeth upon the Earth" on the 6th day are out of sequence with the fowl that fly on the 5th day, since birds descended from theropod dinosaurs 150,000 years ago, well over 100,000 years after reptiles first took to land.
 
 Gee, this account isn't very accurate for the inerrant word of God. It can't get the sequence right, and the time frame is so far off as to be laughable were it not for the fact that some people actually believe this biblical account.
